Award.AwardTitle: Research-Informed Curricula: Creating and Evaluating a Cutting-Edge, Research-Based Physical Geology Textbook

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is creating and evaluating an introductory physical-geology textbook, to be distributed by a commercial publisher, that is informed by research in the learning sciences and pedagogy. The reformed textbook includes stronger integration of figures and text, directly addresses common misconceptions, and provides a leaner approach that emphasizes conceptual understanding and minimizes nonessential terms. The assessment plan, which is integral to the project, includes independent evaluation of the alignment of the materials with cognitive research, student affective and cognitive response, and faculty feedback, providing a basis for testing and revision during development. The potential impact of the reformed textbook is high, given the opportunity to improve student learning in the most-commonly taught geoscience course in the undergraduate curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We created, rigorously evaluated, and iteratively revised innovative college-level introductory physical geology textbook pages guided by a full spectrum of cutting-edge research. Each page of the textbook is informed by research findings and therefore has short blocks of text intimately connected with images, contains simple figures, excludes extraneous terms and details, and directly addresses common misconceptions. Essential to this project was the extensive evaluation, which included both the evaluation of the cognitive instructional design used in the textbook to promote student learning and an evaluation of student learning and attitudes. Both aspects of evaluation informed the production of the pages, turning the envisioned textbook pages into pedagogically-sound, research-supported learning tools.

These innovative textbook pages improved student learning of fundamental geoscience concepts more than the learning achieved by pages from a traditional textbook. The majority of students also preferred to learn from these textbook pages and felt that their approach and design helped them more effectively learn the content. The evaluation of the pages added to the body of knowledge of how to develop effective curricula by applying theoretical cognitive research to instructional design. Use of this textbook may potentially contribute to a shift towards using pedagogically-researched learning materials in geoscience teaching.

This cognitive research-based textbook will potentially have a high impact on student learning by transforming the style, role, and usage of the textbook in the geosciences, and ultimately in other science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines. The textbook itself, the methods used to develop it, and the results from the evaluation of the link between its innovative approach and student learning have been broadly and proactively disseminated to instructors through workshops, presentations at meetings, research publications, an advisory group of potential adopters, and extensive marketing strategies through a publisher. As instructors adopt this relatively low-cost book, their students will benefit from a deeper understanding of geoscience topics, and specific groups, such as pre-service teachers, will have a higher ultimate impact when they incorporate this deeper understanding when teaching others. The purposeful consultation with a diverse group of students with various backgrounds and cultures during both the creation and evaluation of the textbook is designed to result in an increase in the appeal of the textbook to the majority of students, including underrepresented students, thus potentially increasing their interest in the geosciences. This textbook will have far-reaching effects and benefit society by making the geosciences more "down to Earth" and understandable to the general population.
